Date: February 14, 2024

I am writing to summarize the care you received during your recent hospital stay. You were admitted to the hospital on February 10, 2024, with symptoms that included cough, shortness of breath, hemoptysis, and fever. Upon admission, you were diagnosed with lobar pneumonia, unspecified organism, which was supported by chest X-ray findings revealing consolidation in the left lower lobe.

During your stay, you were treated under DRG code 193, which pertains to simple pneumonia and pleurisy with MCC. On admission, your vital signs indicated a fever with a temperature of 38.5°C, a heart rate of 90 bpm, blood pressure at 130/85 mmHg, a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation at 92%.

Empirical antibiotic therapy was initiated immediately with Amoxicillin IV. The initial treatment included a dosage of 500 mg administered every eight hours, along with Paracetamol prescribed as needed. As your condition showed signs of improvement, your CRP levels steadily declined from an initial 60 mg/L to 20 mg/L by February 13, 2024. Similarly, your white blood cell count decreased from 12 x10^9/L to 7 x10^9/L over the course of your stay.

Your temperature normalized by February 12, 2024, and your oxygen saturation improved to 98%, leading to the plan to switch to oral antibiotics. By February 13, your condition had consistently improved, making you ready for discharge.

Upon discharge, you have been provided with oral Amoxicillin to be taken at 250 mg daily for the next five days. Additionally, you are advised to continue taking Atorvastatin PO at a dosage of 20 mg nightly. It is important to adhere to this regimen and monitor for any adverse reactions.

Arrangements have been made for a follow-up appointment at the outpatient clinic in two weeks to ensure your continued recovery and well-being. Please do not hesitate to reach out to us if you experience any new or worsening symptoms before then.

Thank you for allowing us to care for you. We wish you a smooth recovery and good health ahead.
